suppose i am having array of states like ["Todo","done",........] and i wanted to store that array inside the array of workflow [states] in react js
1 / 1

In React.js, if you want to store an array of states inside an array called "workflow," you can define the initial state using the useState hook. Here's an example:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const YourComponent = () => {
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState(["Todo", "Done"]);

  return (
    <div>
      {/* Render your component */}
    </div>
  );
};

export default YourComponent;

In the example above, the useState hook is used to define the initial state of the workflow array. The initial state is set to ["Todo", "Done"]. You can add or remove elements from this array as needed.

Note that the example code assumes you have imported the necessary React dependencies and wrapped your component in a root component (not shown in the example). Make sure you have the required dependencies and proper component structure in your project.

Apologies for the misunderstanding. If you want to store an array of states inside an array called workflow in React.js, you can achieve it by creating an array of objects where each object represents a state. Here's an example:

jsx
import React from 'react';

const YourComponent = () => {
  const workflow = [
    { state: "Todo" },
    { state: "Done" },
    // Add more states as needed
  ];

  return (
    <div>
      {/* Render your component */}
    </div>
  );
};

export default YourComponent;

In this example, the workflow array is defined with each state represented as an object. Each object has a property called state that stores the state's value. You can add as many states as required by creating additional objects in the array.

Please note that the code provided assumes you have the necessary React dependencies and the proper component structure in your project.

Apologies for the confusion. If you want to store an array of states inside an array called workflow in React.js, you can simply create an array and assign it as a value to the workflow array element. Here's an example:

jsx
import React from 'react';

const YourComponent = () => {
  const states = ["Todo", "Done"];
  const workflow = [states, /* more arrays of states */];

  return (
    <div>
      {/* Render your component */}
    </div>
  );
};

export default YourComponent;

In this example, the states array holds the individual states. Then, you can create an array called workflow and assign the states array (or other arrays of states) as elements of the workflow array. You can add as many arrays of states as required by adding them to the workflow array.

Please note that the code provided assumes you have the necessary React dependencies and the proper component structure in your project.

array of states and array of workflow both are dynamic

If both the array of states and the array of workflows are dynamic, you can use the state management in React to handle their updates. Here's an example:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const YourComponent = () => {
  const [states, setStates] = useState(["Todo", "Done"]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  // Function to add a new workflow
  const addWorkflow = () => {
    setWorkflow([...workflow, states]);
  };

  return (
    <div>
      {/* Render your component */}
      <button onClick={addWorkflow}>Add Workflow</button>
    </div>
  );
};

export default YourComponent;

In this example, states is the dynamic array that stores the individual states. The workflow array will hold arrays of states. We use the useState hook to initialize and update these arrays.

The addWorkflow function is called when a button is clicked, which adds the current states array to the workflow array using the spread operator.

You can modify the states array dynamically through some other functionality or user input. This will update the workflow array accordingly when you call the addWorkflow function.

Remember to import the necessary React dependencies and ensure the appropriate component structure in your project.

If the states array can contain multiple states dynamically, and the workflow array can contain multiple arrays of states dynamically, you can follow this approach in React.js:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const YourComponent = () => {
  const [states, setStates] = useState([]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  // Function to add a new state to the states array
  const addState = () => {
    setStates([...states, "New State"]);
  };

  // Function to add a new workflow with the current states array
  const addWorkflow = () => {
    setWorkflow([...workflow, [...states]]);
  };

  return (
    <div>
      {/* Render your component */}
      <button onClick={addState}>Add State</button>
      <button onClick={addWorkflow}>Add Workflow</button>
    </div>
  );
};

export default YourComponent;

In this example, the states array is initially empty, and the workflow array is also initially empty.

The addState function adds a new state ("New State" in this example) to the states array using the spread operator.

The addWorkflow function adds the current states array to the workflow array. It creates a new array by spreading the elements of the states array.

You can add more states dynamically by calling the addState function and create multiple arrays of states within the workflow array by calling the addWorkflow function.

Remember to import the necessary React dependencies and ensure the appropriate component structure in your project.

In your code snippet, you have declared the states array as an array of objects with a property called state. Then, you have declared the workFlow array as an array of objects with a property called workFlow, which contains the states array.

If you want to combine the declarations to have a 2D array structure directly, you can do so by declaring the workFlow array as an array of arrays. Here's an example:

jsx
const [workFlow, setWorkFlow] = useState([[]]);

In this case, the workFlow array is initialized as an array containing an empty array []. This sets up the structure for storing multiple arrays of states inside the workFlow array.

Later, when you add or update the states array, you can update the workFlow array accordingly, ensuring that each element of the workFlow array represents an array of states.

Remember to update the state using the appropriate setter function, such as setWorkFlow, whenever you modify the workFlow array.

Note: If you need to handle complex updates or deep copying of arrays, you may want to consider using a state management library like Redux or immer to handle the nested arrays more efficiently.

To declare the state inside the 2D array workFlow, you can use the useState hook to initialize and update the state. Here's an example:

jsx
const [workFlow, setWorkFlow] = useState([[]]);

// Function to update the state in the 2D array
const updateState = (rowIndex, columnIndex, newState) => {
  setWorkFlow(prevWorkFlow => {
    const newWorkFlow = [...prevWorkFlow]; // Shallow copy of the workFlow array
    newWorkFlow[rowIndex][columnIndex] = newState; // Update the state at the specified row and column
    return newWorkFlow;
  });
};

In the example above, the updateState function is used to update the state at a specific row and column index in the workFlow array. It takes the rowIndex, columnIndex, and newState as parameters.

Inside the setWorkFlow function, we create a shallow copy of the prevWorkFlow array using the spread operator. Then, we update the state at the specified rowIndex and columnIndex with the newState value.

Make sure to call the updateState function whenever you need to update the state inside the workFlow array.

Remember to import the necessary React dependencies and ensure the appropriate component structure in your project.

Yes, you can write the state declaration like this:

jsx
const [workFlow, setWorkFlow] = useState([[{ state: "" }]]);

In this case, the workFlow state is initialized as a 2D array containing a single element. The element is an array containing a single object { state: "" }. This structure allows you to store states inside the workFlow array.

You can update the state within the workFlow array by modifying the workFlow state directly using the setWorkFlow function. For example, if you want to update the state at a specific index, you can do so as follows:

jsx
const updateState = (rowIndex, columnIndex, newState) => {
  setWorkFlow(prevWorkFlow => {
    const newWorkFlow = [...prevWorkFlow]; // Shallow copy of the workFlow array
    newWorkFlow[rowIndex][columnIndex].state = newState; // Update the state at the specified row and column
    return newWorkFlow;
  });
};

Please note that when updating nested state structures like this, it's important to use proper immutability techniques to ensure the state updates correctly. In the example above, a shallow copy of the prevWorkFlow array is made before updating the state to maintain immutability.

now lets take an example we are having multiple input tags in the form of a 2d-array of input fields rows and columns their can be multiple and different no of input field in each row then write a component in react in which we are able add value inside the input field of having [row no, col no]
1 / 1

Sure! I can provide you with an example component in React that allows you to add values to input fields in a 2D array structure. Here's an example:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex][colIndex] = value; // Update the value at the specified row and column
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, []]);
  };

  const addColumn = rowIndex => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

      {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
        <div key={rowIndex}>
          {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
            <input
              key={colIndex}
              value={value}
              onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
            />
          ))}
          <button onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</button>
        </div>
      ))}
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this example, the inputValues state holds the 2D array structure for the input field values. The handleInputChange function is called whenever an input field value changes. It updates the corresponding value in the inputValues state based on the row and column indices.

The addRow function adds a new row to the inputValues state, and the addColumn function adds a new column to a specific row in the inputValues state.

The component renders a button to add new rows, and for each row, it renders input fields and a button to add new columns. The value prop of each input field is set to the corresponding value from the inputValues state, and the onChange event is handled by the handleInputChange function.

You can use this InputGrid component in your React application to handle and display input fields in a 2D array structure, allowing you to add values based on the row and column indices.

1 / 1

Certainly! Here's an updated version of the InputGrid component that allows you to add new rows with a single input field and add or delete input fields within each row:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex][colIndex] = value; // Update the value at the specified row and column
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const addColumn = rowIndex => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((_, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

      {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
        <div key={rowIndex}>
          {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
            <div key={colIndex}>
              <input
                value={value}
                onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
              />
              {colIndex > 0 && (
                <button onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>Delete</button>
              )}
            </div>
          ))}
          <button onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</button>
        </div>
      ))}
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated version, you can add new rows by clicking the "Add Row" button. Each row initially contains a single input field.

You can add new input fields to a row by clicking the "Add Column" button within the respective row.

To delete an input field within a row, the "Delete" button is rendered for all columns except the first one. Clicking the "Delete" button will remove the corresponding input field from that row.

You can use this updated InputGrid component to dynamically add, delete, and update input fields within rows of a 2D array structure in your React application.

To store the states entered in each row and then store the array of states inside the array of workflows, you can update the InputGrid component as follows:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex][colIndex] = value; // Update the value at the specified row and column
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((_, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

      {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
        <div key={rowIndex}>
          {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
            <div key={colIndex}>
              <input
                value={value}
                onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
              />
              {colIndex > 0 && (
                <button onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>Delete</button>
              )}
            </div>
          ))}
          <button onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</button>
        </div>
      ))}

      <div>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated version, the handleSubmitRow function is called when the "Submit" button of each row is clicked. It retrieves the states entered in that row, filters out any empty or whitespace-only values, and then adds the resulting array of states to the workflow array using the setWorkflow function.

The workflow array is rendered at the bottom of the component, displaying the stored arrays of states.

Now, when you enter states in each row and click the "Submit" button, the entered states will be stored in the workflow array.

Remember to import the necessary React dependencies and ensure the appropriate component structure in your project.

Apologies for the confusion. To display columns horizontally and rows vertically, you can update the rendering logic in the InputGrid component. Here's an updated version:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex][colIndex] = value; // Update the value at the specified row and column
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, Array(inputValues[0].length).fill("")]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map(row => [...row, ""]);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const deleteColumn = (colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map(row => row.filter((_, index) => index !== colIndex));
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>
      <button onClick={addColumn}>Add Column</button>

      <div className="grid-container">
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <div key={rowIndex} className="grid-row">
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <div key={colIndex} className="grid-cell">
                <input
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
              </div>
            ))}
            <button onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</button>
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>

      <div>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated version, the inputValues state is initialized as an array of arrays, where each inner array represents a row, and the columns are created horizontally.

The "Add Row" button adds a new row, and the "Add Column" button adds a new column to all rows. The "Submit" button is placed at the end of each row.

The CSS classes grid-container, grid-row, and grid-cell are used to style the grid layout.

Now, the columns will be displayed horizontally, and rows will be displayed vertically, giving you the desired layout.

Remember to import the necessary React dependencies and define the required CSS styles for the grid layout in your project.

Apologies for the confusion. Here's an updated version of the InputGrid component that adds rows with one input field and increases columns horizontally:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex][colIndex] = value; // Update the value at the specified row and column
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues]; // Shallow copy of the inputValues array
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

      <div className="grid-container">
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <div key={rowIndex} className="grid-row">
            <div className="grid-cell">
              <input
                value={row[0]}
                onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, 0, event)}
              />
            </div>
            {row.slice(1).map((value, colIndex) => (
              <div key={colIndex} className="grid-cell">
                <input
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex + 1, event)}
                />
              </div>
            ))}
            <button onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</button>
            <button onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</button>
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>

      <div>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated version, when you click the "Add Row" button, a new row is added with one input field (col1) by default.

The "Add Column" button is placed after each input field, allowing you to add additional columns to the row.

The "Submit" button is also placed after each input field to submit the row.

The columns increase horizontally, and rows are displayed vertically as per your requirement.

Remember to import the necessary React dependencies and define the required CSS styles for the grid layout in your project.

I apologize for the confusion. Here's an updated version of the InputGrid component that adds rows with one input field and increases columns horizontally:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map(row => [...row, ""]);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

      <div className="grid-container">
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <div key={rowIndex} className="grid-row">
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <div key={colIndex} className="grid-cell">
                <input
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
              </div>
            ))}
            <button onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</button>
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>

      <div>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated version, the columns are added horizontally, maintaining the rows in a vertical manner. Each row contains one input field initially, and you can click the "Add Row" button to add a new row with one input field.

The "Add Row" button adds a new row with one input field at the end of the grid.

The "Submit" button is placed at the end of each row, allowing you to submit the row and store the states in the workflow array.

Please ensure you have appropriate CSS styling for the grid layout in your project.

Apologies for the confusion. Here's an updated version of the InputGrid component that adds rows with one input field and includes an "Add Column" button:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map(row => [...row, ""]);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

      <div className="grid-container">
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <div key={rowIndex} className="grid-row">
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <div key={colIndex} className="grid-cell">
                <input
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
              </div>
            ))}
            <button onClick={addColumn}>Add Column</button>
            <button onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</button>
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>

      <div>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated version, the "Add Column" button is placed after each row. Clicking the "Add Column" button will add a new column to all rows, expanding the grid horizontally.

Please ensure you have appropriate CSS styling for the grid layout in your project.

Apologies for the confusion. If you want the "Add Column" button to add an input field only to the row from which it is clicked, you can modify the addColumn function to accept the rowIndex as a parameter. Here's the updated version of the InputGrid component:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {

Apologies for the confusion. To achieve the desired behavior where each row has its own "Add Column" button and clicking the button adds an input field only to that particular row, you can modify the addColumn function to accept the rowIndex as a parameter. Here's the updated version of the InputGrid component:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={addRow}>Add Row</button>

                />

Certainly! Here's an updated version of the InputGrid component using React Bootstrap classes instead of external CSS:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow}>Add Row</Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center">
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this version, React Bootstrap components such as Container, Row, Col, Button, and Form.Control are used to achieve the desired layout. Please ensure that you have installed and imported React Bootstrap in your project for these components to work properly.

Apologies for the confusion in my previous response. To make the columns display in a horizontal line using Flexbox, you can update the InputGrid component as follows:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

            </Col>
            <Col className="d-flex">

            </Col>

            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

By adding the d-flex class to the <Col> components, the columns will be displayed in a horizontal line. This class sets display: flex on the column, making the elements inside it flow horizontally.

Make sure you have the necessary CSS styles and React Bootstrap components imported in your project for this code to work properly.

now add "-" button after each input tag which will be able to delete that specific input tag when the "-" button is clicked
1 / 1

To add a "-" button after each input tag that can delete the specific input when clicked, you can modify the InputGrid component as follows:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow}>Add Row</Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated code, I've added a new function called deleteColumn that handles the deletion of a specific input tag. The function takes the rowIndex and colIndex as parameters and updates the inputValues state by filtering out the specific column from the corresponding row.

I've also added a "-" button next to each input tag, which triggers the deleteColumn function when clicked. The deleteColumn function is passed the current rowIndex and colIndex to identify the specific input to delete.

With these changes, you should now have the ability to delete specific input tags when the "-" button is clicked. Let me know if you have any further questions!

To ensure that at least one input tag is rendered initially, you can modify the InputGrid component by setting a minimum number of columns per row.

Here's an updated version of the InputGrid component that guarantees at least one input tag per row on the initial render:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[{ value: "" }]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => {
            if (cIndex === colIndex) {
              return { value };
            }
            return col;
          });
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [{ value: "" }]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].map(col => col.value).filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], { value: "" }];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow}>Add Row</Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((col, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={col.value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                {colIndex === 0 && (
                  <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>
                    -
                  </Button>
                )}
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated code, the inputValues state is initialized with at least one input tag in each row by using an object with a value property. When rendering the input tag, we check if it's the first column (colIndex === 0), and if so, we render the "-" button.

With these changes, there will always be at least one input tag in each row when the component is initially rendered. Feel free to modify the code as needed to fit your specific requirements. Let me know if you have any further questions!

import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[{ value: "" }]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => {
            if (cIndex === colIndex) {
              return { value };
            }
            return col;
          });
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [{ value: "" }]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].map(col => col.value).filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], { value: "" }];
      return newInputValues;
    });

                <Col>
                  <Form.Control
                    type="text"
                    value={col.value}
                    onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                  />

                <Col>

                </Col>

            ))}
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>

            ))}
          </div>
        ))}

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[{ value: "" }]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => {
            if (cIndex === colIndex) {
              return { value };
            }
            return col;
          });
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [{ value: "" }]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].map(col => col.value).filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {

      newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], { value: "" }];
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

To prevent adding a new column if any of the input fields in the row are empty, you can add a check before adding a new column. If any of the input fields have an empty value, you can disable the "Add Column" button. Here's an updated version of the code with this functionality:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (inputValues[rowIndex].every(value => value.trim() !== "")) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow}>Add Row</Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {row.every(value => value.trim() !== "") ? (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
              ) : null}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

In this updated code, the "Add Column" button is disabled if any of the input fields in the row are empty. This ensures that all input fields in a row must be filled before adding a new column.

1 / 1

To allow adding a new row only when the previous row is submitted, you can introduce a state variable to track the submission status of each row. Here's an updated version of the code that implements this functionality:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);
  const [submittedRows, setSubmittedRows] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    if (submittedRows.length === inputValues.length) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
    }
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
    setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (inputValues[rowIndex].every(value => value.trim() !== "")) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow} disabled={submittedRows.length !== inputValues.length}>
        Add Row
      </Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {row.every(value => value.trim() !== "") ? (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
              ) : null}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button
                variant="primary"
                onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}
                disabled={submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)}
              >
                Submit
              </Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

1 / 1

Apologies for the oversight. To prevent submitting rows with empty input fields, we can add a check before allowing the submission. Here's the updated code:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);
  const [submittedRows, setSubmittedRows] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    if (submittedRows.length === inputValues.length) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
    }
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    if (rowStates.length > 0) {
      setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
      setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
    }
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (inputValues[rowIndex].every(value => value.trim() !== "")) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
      newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow} disabled={submittedRows.length !== inputValues.length}>
        Add Row
      </Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {row.every(value => value.trim() !== "") ? (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
              ) : null}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button
                variant="primary"
                onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}
                disabled={submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) || row.every(value => value.trim() === "")}
              >
                Submit
              </Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

Now, the "Add Row" button is disabled when there are any rows that haven't been submitted yet, and the "Submit" button is disabled for already submitted rows or rows with empty input fields.

Apologies for the confusion. To fix the issue where deleting an input field in a submitted row prevents it from being resubmitted, we need to update the logic in the deleteColumn function.

Here's the updated code that allows resubmission after deleting an input field:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);
  const [submittedRows, setSubmittedRows] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    if (submittedRows.length === inputValues.length) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
    }
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    if (rowStates.length > 0) {
      setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, rowStates]);
      setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
    }
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (inputValues[rowIndex].every(value => value.trim() !== "")) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.filter((col, cIndex) => cIndex !== colIndex);
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow} disabled={submittedRows.length !== inputValues.length}>
        Add Row
      </Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {row.every(value => value.trim() !== "") ? (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
              ) : null}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button
                variant="primary"
                onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}
                disabled={submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) || row.every(value => value.trim() === "")}
              >
                Submit
              </Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;

With this updated code, you should be able to delete an input field in a submitted row and resubmit the row again.

To print the submitted row in the console as the first element in the workflow array, you can modify the handleSubmitRow function as follows:

jsx
const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
  const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
  if (rowStates.length > 0) {
    console.log(rowStates); // Print the submitted row in the console
    setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [rowStates, ...prevWorkflow]); // Add the rowStates as the first element in the workflow array
    setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
  }
};

This code will log the submitted row to the console and add it as the first element in the workflow array using the spread operator (...prevWorkflow). The rest of the elements in the workflow array will be shifted to the right.

Make sure to place this modified handleSubmitRow function inside your InputGrid component.

import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);
  const [submittedRows, setSubmittedRows] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {

  };

Certainly! Here's the updated code with the modifications to prevent submitting empty columns and allow adding a new row only when the previous row is submitted:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);
  const [submittedRows, setSubmittedRows] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    if (submittedRows.includes(inputValues.length - 1)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
    }
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    const isRowFilled = rowStates.length === inputValues[rowIndex].length;

    if (isRowFilled) {
      console.log(rowStates); // Print the submitted row in the console
      setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, [rowStates]]); // Add the rowStates as a new array inside the workflow array
      setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
    }
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow}>Add Row</Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                  <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
                )}
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
              )}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
              )}
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>

          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}

Apologies for the confusion. To prevent adding a new column when the previous column is empty, you can update the addColumn function to check if the last column in the current row is filled before allowing the addition of a new column. Here's the modified addColumn function:

jsx
const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
  if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
    const lastColIndex = inputValues[rowIndex].length - 1;
    const isLastColFilled = inputValues[rowIndex][lastColIndex].trim() !== "";

    if (isLastColFilled) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  }
};

This code checks if the last column in the current row is filled by trimming the value and checking if it's an empty string. If it's not empty, a new column is added. Otherwise, no new column is added.

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { Container, Row, Col, Button, Form } from 'react-bootstrap';

const InputGrid = () => {
  const [inputValues, setInputValues] = useState([[""]]);
  const [workflow, setWorkflow] = useState([]);
  const [submittedRows, setSubmittedRows] = useState([]);

  const handleInputChange = (rowIndex, colIndex, event) => {
    const { value } = event.target;

    setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
      const newInputValues = prevInputValues.map((row, rIndex) => {
        if (rIndex === rowIndex) {
          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    if (submittedRows.includes(inputValues.length - 1)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
    }
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    const isRowFilled = rowStates.length === inputValues[rowIndex].length;

    if (isRowFilled) {
      console.log(rowStates); // Print the submitted row in the console
      setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, [rowStates]]); // Add the rowStates as a new array inside the workflow array
      setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
    }
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
      const lastColIndex = inputValues[rowIndex].length - 1;
      const isLastColFilled = inputValues[rowIndex][lastColIndex].trim() !== "";

      if (isLastColFilled) {
        setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
          const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
          newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
          return newInputValues;
        });
      }
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow}>Add Row</Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                  <Button variant="danger" onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}>-</Button>
                )}
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}>Add Column</Button>
              )}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                <Button variant="primary" onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}>Submit</Button>
              )}
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
  if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
    const lastColIndex = inputValues[rowIndex].length - 1;
    const isLastColFilled = inputValues[rowIndex][lastColIndex].trim() !== "";

    if (isLastColFilled) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
        return newInputValues;

  }

          return row.map((col, cIndex) => (cIndex === colIndex ? value : col));
        }
        return row;
      });

      return newInputValues;
    });
  };

  const addRow = () => {
    if (submittedRows.includes(inputValues.length - 1)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => [...prevInputValues, [""]]);
    }
  };

  const handleSubmitRow = (rowIndex) => {
    const rowStates = inputValues[rowIndex].filter(value => value.trim() !== "");
    const isRowFilled = rowStates.length === inputValues[rowIndex].length;

    if (isRowFilled) {
      console.log(rowStates); // Print the submitted row in the console
      setWorkflow(prevWorkflow => [...prevWorkflow, [rowStates]]); // Add the rowStates as a new array inside the workflow array
      setSubmittedRows(prevSubmittedRows => [...prevSubmittedRows, rowIndex]);
    }
  };

  const addColumn = (rowIndex) => {
    if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
      const lastColIndex = inputValues[rowIndex].length - 1;
      const isLastColFilled = inputValues[rowIndex][lastColIndex].trim() !== "";

      if (isLastColFilled) {
        setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
          const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
          newInputValues[rowIndex] = [...newInputValues[rowIndex], ""];
          return newInputValues;
        });
      }
    }
  };

  const deleteColumn = (rowIndex, colIndex) => {
    if (!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)) {
      setInputValues(prevInputValues => {
        const newInputValues = [...prevInputValues];
        newInputValues[rowIndex] = newInputValues[rowIndex].filter((col, index) => index !== colIndex);
        return newInputValues;
      });
    }
  };

  return (
    <Container>
      <Button variant="primary" onClick={addRow} disabled={inputValues.length > 0 && !submittedRows.includes(inputValues.length - 1)}>
        Add Row
      </Button>

      <Container>
        {inputValues.map((row, rowIndex) => (
          <Row key={rowIndex} className="mb-3 align-items-center" style={{ display: 'flex' }}>
            {row.map((value, colIndex) => (
              <Col key={colIndex}>
                <Form.Control
                  type="text"
                  value={value}
                  onChange={event => handleInputChange(rowIndex, colIndex, event)}
                />
                {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                  <Button
                    variant="danger"
                    onClick={() => deleteColumn(rowIndex, colIndex)}
                    disabled={submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)}
                  >
                    -
                  </Button>
                )}
              </Col>
            ))}
            <Col>
              {!submittedRows.includes(rowIndex) && (
                <Button
                  variant="primary"
                  onClick={() => addColumn(rowIndex)}
                  disabled={!row.every(val => val.trim() !== "") || submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)}
                >
                  Add Column
                </Button>
              )}
            </Col>
            <Col>
              <Button
                variant="primary"
                onClick={() => handleSubmitRow(rowIndex)}
                disabled={!row.every(val => val.trim() !== "") || submittedRows.includes(rowIndex)}
              >
                Submit
              </Button>
            </Col>
          </Row>
        ))}
      </Container>

      <Container>
        <h2>Workflow</h2>
        {workflow.map((rowStates, index) => (
          <div key={index}>
            {rowStates.map((state, stateIndex) => (
              <span key={stateIndex}>{state}</span>
            ))}
          </div>
        ))}
      </Container>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default InputGrid;
